edu.umass.cs.sensors.falcon
Class APPM

java.lang.Object
  edu.umass.cs.sensors.falcon.APPM

public class APPM
extends Object

Class implementing APPM algorithm

APPM algorithm has two components:

  • Prediction Model: Refer PPM for details
  • Temporal Model: Refer TemporalModel for details

The following details assume that you have read the documentation of above two models. Now, we describe the steps in using APPM.

Instantiate Models

The first step is to indicate:
  • N_PREDICTIONS_TO_GET i.e. the number of top predictions to get for the next likely event.
  • N_MODELS_CONTEXT1 i.e. Cardinality of the first context associated with the event. For example, if HOUR OF DAY is the context associated with the event then its cardinality is 24. Use a number ≤ 0 if context-specific prediction is not desired.
  • N_MODELS_CONTEXT2 i.e. Cardinality of the second context associated with the event. Use a number ≤ 0 if context-specific prediction is not desired.
  • N_TIME_BINS Number of temporal models to create. This number should be at least 1. A value greater than 1 will divide the duration of the day into N_TIME_BINS equal periods and will create a unique temporal model for each period.
Now, create an APPM instance as follows: 
APPM appm = new APPM(N_PREDICTIONS_TO_GET, N_MODELS_CONTEXT1, N_MODELS_CONTEXT2, N_TIME_BINS);

Register Events

Now, Specify the list of event names for which temporal model must be created. Example: 
 LinkedList<String> events = new LinkedList<String>();
 events.add("Email");
 events.add("Facebook");
 appm.registerEventsForTemporalModeling(events);

Updating Models and Getting Predictions, Event Likelihoods

For any system observing a sequence of events, it must update APPM models with the latest observed event. Once the models have been updated, we can use it to predict the next event likely to occur or to compute likelihood of the event to occur within some interval. Example code: 
 //Let 'Email' be observed at UTC time '1368468829000' at 4th hour of day (first context).
 appm.addEventObservation(1368468829L, 'Email', 3, 0);
 
 //Get top-k predictions for the next event and assuming the contexts remain the same.
 String predictedEvents[] = appm.getEventPredictions(3, 0);
 for(int i=0;i<predictedEvents.length;i++)
 	System.out.println("Predicted Event at Rank "+i+" "+predictedEvents[i]);
 
 //Get likelihood of event 'Facebook' to occur in next 5 minutes 
 //if the current UTC time is '1368468830000'. Assuming the contexts remain the same.
 String targetEvents[] = new String[]{"Facebook"};
 long delta = 5*60*1000L;
 double likelihood[] = appm.getEventLikelihoodInDeltaTime(1368468830000L, delta, 3, 0, targetEvents);
 for(int i=0;i<likelihood.length;i++)
 	System.out.println("Likelihood of "+targetEvents[i]+" is "+likelihood[i]);

Abhinav Parate aparate@cs.umass.edu

Field Detail

NUM_PREDICTIONS

public static int NUM_PREDICTIONS
Number of events to predict

Constructor Detail

APPM

public APPM(int N_PREDICTIONS_TO_GET,
            int N_MODELS_CONTEXT1,
            int N_MODELS_CONTEXT2,
            int N_TIME_BINS)
Constructor for APPM. Use a number ≤ 0 if context-specific predictions are not desired. Set N_TIME_BINS to at least 1 as at least 1 temporal model is needed.

Parameters:
N_PREDICTIONS_TO_GET - number of events that will be predicted
N_MODELS_CONTEXT1 - number of models to create for first context type
N_MODELS_CONTEXT2 - number of models to create for second context type
N_TIME_BINS - number of temporal models to create for a day
Method Detail

registerEventsForTemporalModeling

public void registerEventsForTemporalModeling(LinkedList<String> events)
Registers events for which temporal model is needed.

Temporal model is created only for the registered events to save computation and memory.

Parameters:
events - list of events

addEventObservation

public void addEventObservation(long eventTime,
                                String eventName,
                                int indexModelContext1,
                                int indexModelContext2)
Add an event observation along with associated contexts

Parameters:
eventTime - time of event observation
eventName - name of the observed event
indexModelContext1 - index to the model for the first context type
indexModelContext2 - index to the model for the second context type

getEventPredictions

public String[] getEventPredictions(int indexModelContext1,
                                    int indexModelContext2)
Returns an array of top k predicted events for a given context where k is NUM_EVENTS_TO_PREDICT

Parameters:
indexModelContext1 - index to the model for the first context to be used in calculating predictions
indexModelContext2 - index to the model for the second context to be used in calculating predictions
Returns:
array of predicted events

getEventLikelihoodInDeltaTime

public double[] getEventLikelihoodInDeltaTime(long currentTime,
                                              long deltaTime,
                                              int indexModelContext1,
                                              int indexModelContext2,
                                              String[] events)
Get the likelihood of events to occur within some interval

Likelihoods will be 0 if the event was not observed before for this time of the day.

Parameters:
currentTime - time at which likelihood is to be determined (in milliseconds)
deltaTime - interval in milliseconds
indexModelContext1 - index to the model for the first context to be used in calculating likelihood
indexModelContext2 - index to the model for the second context to be used in calculating likelihood
events - list of events for which likelihood is needed
Returns:
an array consisting of likelihood of events

main

public static void main(String[] args)
Example demonstrating how to use APPM. Uses randomly generated sequence of events.

Parameters:
args - none
